fields.label_text: The following is the label text from 1971 for Galleries 1-7 of the V&A: "AN UNKNOWN GIRL Atrributed to MARIE-JEANNE DORÉ (b. 1736) Inscribed on parapet: Melle. Dore. French School, about 1765. In an 18th century carved frame. This painting has close affinity with the work of François-Hubert Drouais (1727-75) and it was formerly described as a portrait of Mademoiselle Doré by Drouais. However, there was a portrait painter who signed herself Mlle Dore in 1763 and 1765-about the time when this picture was painted-and it seems likely that, in this case also, Mademoiselle Doré was the painter rather than the sitter. She is probably to be indentified with Marie-Jeane Doré, Drouais' sister in law. Jones Collection. Museum No. 600-1882."

fields.descriptive_line: Oil painting, 'Portrait of  Mademoiselle Doré', François-Hubert Drouais, before 1758

fields.name: Female creators: Woman Artists from the Era of Vigee Le Brun

fields.physical_description: In an oval format, set against a neutral grey background, bust portrait of a young lady wearing a blue dress and a blue hat held by a large knot under her chin, holding a rose in her right hand and leaning against a parapet.
fields.dimensions: Height: 68.6 cm estimate, Width: 61 cm estimate, Height: 84.5 cm framed, Width: 75 cm framed, Depth: 10.4 cm framed
fields.title: Portrait of Mlle Doré; Portrait of Mlle Doré
fields.label: The following is the label text from 1971 for Galleries 1-7 of the V&A: "AN UNKNOWN GIRL Atrributed to MARIE-JEANNE DORÉ (b. 1736) Inscribed on parapet: Melle. Dore. French School, about 1765. In an 18th century carved frame. This painting has close affinity with the work of François-Hubert Drouais (1727-75) and it was formerly described as a portrait of Mademoiselle Doré by Drouais. However, there was a portrait painter who signed herself Mlle Dore in 1763 and 1765-about the time when this picture was painted-and it seems likely that, in this case also, Mademoiselle Doré was the painter rather than the sitter. She is probably to be indentified with Marie-Jeane Doré, Drouais' sister in law. Jones Collection. Museum No. 600-1882."
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, room 315, case 24, shelf L
fields.public_access_description:
François Hubert Drouais (1727-1775) was born in Paris. He trained with his father, Hubert Drouais (1699-1767) and then with Donat Nonotte (1708-1785), Carle van Loo (1705-1765), Charles-Joseph Natoire (1700-1777) and François Boucher (1703-1770). He became a member of the Académie Royale in 1755 and achieved quickly a great success as a portrait painter, receiving prestigious commissions, especially from the court.

This painting depicts a young lady  whose costume is datable ca. 1760. She is identified by an inscription on the parapet reading ‘Mlle Doré’, which could refer to either the future wife of the painter, Anne-Françoise Doré or her sister, Marie-Jeanne. This painting is a good example of Drouais’ production of portraits, a category in which he specialised with success.
fields.exhibition_history: Female creators: Woman Artists from the Era of Vigee Le Brun (Mitsubishi Ichigokan 01/03/2011-08/05/2011)
fields.bibliography: C.M. Kauffmann, Catalogue of Foreign Paintings, I. Before 1800, London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 1973, p. 87, cat. no. 87 The following is the full text of the entry: "Mademoiselle DORÉ (active c. 1760-70) French school Probably to be identified with Marie- Jeanne Doré (b. 1736), the sister-in-law of François-Hubert Drouais (1727-75), see below. 87 AN UNKNOWN GIRL HOLDING A ROSE IN HER RIGHT HAND Inscribed on parapet Melle Doré Canvas, oval 27 x 24 (68.6 x 61) Jones Bequest 600-1882 The close affinity with Drouais' style led to the original attribution to this artist, which was accepted by C. Gabillot in 1905. This attribution was supported by Drouais' relationship by marriage to the Doré family. On 26 July 1758 he married Anne-Françoise Doré (1732-1809), the eldest of three daughters of Pierre Doré (d. 1751), a locksmith, and his wife Françoise Breche de la Bonté. Of Anne-Françoise's two sisters, Marie-Jeanne was 22 in 1758, and Marie was 12. Marie-Jeanne went to live with the Drouais after their marriage and helped to bring up their children. Gabillot suggested that the sitter was Marie-Jeanne, but Long inclined to the view that the painting depicted Anne-Françoise before her marriage, on the grounds of similarity with Drouais' other portraits of his wife (see especially Gazette des Beaux-Arts,xxxiv, 1905, p. 391, repr.) However, Long admitted that both the attribution to Drouais and the identification of the sitter were inconclusive, and he suggested that the inscription might possibly be a signature. Subsequently, this hypothesis was strengthened by the appearance of two portraits, in a very similar style, both signed Mlle Doré: (1) An unknown man; sale Drouot, Paris, 20-1 Dec. 1937, lot 4 (repr. in catalogue), dated 1763. (2) An unknown woman; sale Fischer, Lucerne, 21-3 Aug. 1930, lot 288 (repr. in catalogue), dated 1765. To judge from the reproductions, these appear to be by the same hand as 600-1882, and it seems likely that this artist is identical with the Mademoiselle Doré who exhibited miniatures in oil at the Exposition de la Jeunesse, Place Dauphine, Paris in 1769. As 600-1882 may be dated c. 1765 from the costume and as the other two paintings are dated 1763 and 1765 respectively, it seems likely that Mademoiselle Doré can be identified with Drouais' sister-in-law, Marie-Jeanne. It is most likely that Anne-Françoise would sign in this manner after her marriage and the youngest sister Marie (aged 17 in 1763) may be excluded on grounds of age. The fact that Marie-Jeanne was staying with the Drouais for some years after 1758 would help to account for the close dependence of her style on that of her famous brother-in-law. This link is stressed in the Drouot sale catalogue (20 Dec. 1937, lot 288). Prov.John Jones; bequeathed to the Museum in 1882. Lit.J. J. Foster, French art from Watteau to Prud'hon,i, 1905, pl, iii (as by an unknown painter); C. Gabillot in Gazette des Beaux-Arts,xxxiv, 1905, p. 392, n. 4 (by Drouais, of Marie-Jeanne Doré); Long, Cat. Jones. Coll.,1923, p. 7, pl. 31 (attributed to Drouais, perhaps of his wife, before their marriage); C. M. Kauffmann in Apollo,xcv, 1972, p. 184, fig. 12." J. J. Foster, French art from Watteau to Prud'hon,i, 1905, pl, iii. As by an unknown painter C. Gabillot in Gazette des Beaux-Arts, xxxiv, 1905, p. 392, n. 4. By Drouais, of Marie-Jeanne Doré. B. Long, Catalogue of the Jones Collection,1923, p. 7, pl. 31. Attributed to Drouais, perhaps of his wife, before their marriage. C. M. Kauffmann in Apollo, xcv, 1972, p. 184, fig. 12. Creer au feminin - Femmes artistes du siecle de Madame Vigee Le Brun Tokyo: Mitsubishi Ichigokan Museum, 2011. Exhibition catalogue
fields.historical_context_note:
The painting was formerly attributed to a certain Mlle Doré, identified as Marie-Jeanne Doré, who is said to have painted miniature portraits, and appears to be the sister-in-law of the French painter François-Hubert Drouais. 

The stylistic characteristics and the two copies after this painting suggest however that the painting was executed by François-Hubert Drouais himself rather than his young sister-in-law. This attribution is supported by M. Alastair Laing (written communication, Jan 2008).

The two copies, one in the Government Art Collection, London, and another sold at Sotheby's London, 1st Nov. 2007, lot 193, are moreover both attributed to Drouais. The inscription on the parapet reading 'Mlle Doré' seems therefore to allude to the identity of the sitter rather than that of the artist. 
 
The sitter could in fact be identified with either the wife of the artist before their marriage (hence the inscription 'Mlle' which stands in French for 'Miss') or her sister, who came to live with the family after the wedding. 

It is most likely however that the V&A painting portrayed the wife of the artist as the sitter is very similar to a portrait of Madame Drouais, wife of the artist, dated ca. 1758 (Louvre, Paris). In the same guise as in our painting, she has some wild roses pressed against her heart and wears a similar blue dress with a large blue knot under her chin.
Carnation and wild roses were often used as a symbol of bethrotal and love. This attribute would therefore illustrate appropriately the bond between the painter and his wife.

Based on the style of the dress, similar to the one in the Louvre portrait, this painting can be reasonably dated c. 1760.

Drouais was a successful portrait painter and was entrusted with a series of royal commissions. This portrait is a fine example of his art, which combines mastery and freshness.
